{{Essay-like|date=December 2014}} {{Globalize/West|date=July 2018}} [[Image:Cartello piedibus.jpg|thumb|Sign for a walking bus stop in the Italian city of [[Zanica]]]] [[File:Haltestellentafel eines Pedibus.jpg|thumb|A walking bus stop in Germany]] A '''walking bus''' is a form of [[student transport]] for schoolchildren who, [[Chaperone (social)|chaperoned]] by two adults (a "Driver" leads and a "conductor" follows), walk to school along a set route, in much the same way a [[school bus]] would drive them to school.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://saferoutespartnership.org/sites/default/files/resource_files/step-by-step-walking-school-bus.pdf|title=Step By Step: How to Start a Walking School Bus|last=Moening|first=Kate|date=2016|website=|publisher=California Department of Public Health|page=2|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref> Like a traditional bus, walking buses have a fixed route with designated "bus stops" and "pick up times" in which they pick up children.
==History==
The concept of the walking bus was first invented in Japan<ref name="Japan">{{cite web | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/302874075_International_Origins_of_Walking_School_Buses_and_Child_Fatalities_in_Japan_and_Canada | title = International Origins of Walking School Buses and Child Fatalities in Japan and Canada | accessdate = 2018-10-27 | author = Edward Owen D. Waygood, Ayako Taniguchi, Catherine Craig-St-Louis, Xin Xu }}</ref> Australian transport activist [[David Engwicht]]<ref name="David Engwicht">{{cite web | url = http://www.lesstraffic.com/Articles/Traffic/wbstalled.htm | title = Is the Walking Bus stalled? | accessdate = 2009-06-16 | author = [[David Engwicht]] }}</ref> is often given credit for inventing the WSB system in the 1990s. It was introduced in the United Kingdom in 1998 by [[Hertfordshire County Council]]. It was first used by pupils of [[Wheatfields Junior School]] in [[St Albans]], [[United Kingdom]] in 1998 <ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/880055.stm BBC News Article]</ref>
Walking Buses have remained popular in the [[United Kingdom]] and have recently gained a level of popularity elsewhere in Europe, North America<ref>"[http://www.walkingschoolbus.org/ Start a Walking School Bus]", Partnership for a Walkable America</ref> and [[New Zealand]]. Proponents of walking buses say that its aims are to:<ref>[http://www.iwalktoschool.org/ The Official Website of International Walk to School]</ref>
*Encourage physical activity by teaching children the skills to walk safely, how to identify safe routes to school, and the benefits of walking *Raise awareness of extent of a community's walkability and where improvements can be made *Raise concern for the environment *Reduce crime and take back neighborhoods for people on foot *Reduce traffic congestion, pollution, and speed near schools *Share valuable time with local community leaders, parents, and children
In [[Auckland]], New Zealand, as of November 2007, one hundred schools run 230 Walking School Buses with over 4,000 children and 1,500 adults participating.<ref>[http://www.travelwise.org.nz/media/pdf/2007_STPeval.pdf Auckland Regional Transport Authority School Travel Evaluation for the 2007 school year]</ref>
In some countries, parents and/or children on walking buses are encouraged to wear brightly coloured jackets or waistcoats. This has led to criticism that the walking bus is too regimented, and fails to achieve its original purpose of improving children's independent mobility. [[David Engwicht]], whose 1992 book "Reclaiming our Cities and Towns" is credited by some as the origin of the Walking School Bus concept, has since stated that "The moment the Walking Bus turns into an official program, it creates some significant difficulties, particularly in litigious and risk-adverse cultures."<ref name="David Engwicht"/>
== Public health == [[File:Walking bus stop, Station Road - geograph.org.uk - 291411.jpg|thumb|Walking bus stop.]] The walking school bus can help to reduce [[childhood obesity]] rates in the United States by increasing active transportation to school. The [[American Public Health Association]] cites that participation in active transportation to school has reduced by a third in the last 40 years.<ref name=Association2012>{{Citation | title = Safe Routes to School: Helping All Students Walk and Bike Safely | url = http://www.apha.org/NR/rdonlyres/6BB76167-4480-405F-A3F9-3FBB6B82D938/0/APHASafeRoutestoSchoolFactSheetNovember2011.pdf | year = 2012 | author = Association, American Public Health | accessdate = 2012-07-16 }}</ref> The reduction in active transportation has coincided with an increase in childhood obesity rates. The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) reports the prevalence of obesity among children has doubled and among adolescents has quadrupled in the past 30 years. In 2012, 18% of children and 21% of adolescents were obese.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/obesity/facts.htm|title=Obesity Prevention {{!}} Healthy Schools {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref>
According to the Safe Routes to School National Partnership, 1 mile of walking equates to 2/3rds of the recommendation of 60 minutes a day.<ref>http://saferoutespartnership.org/</ref> In addition to the potential health benefits, the walking school bus can help children arrive to school safely, on time, and ready to learn. Walking to school counts towards the recommended 60 minutes of physical activity a day.<ref>http://saferoutespartnership.org</ref> Another benefit is the positive association between physical activity and improved academic performance. In a study done by the CDC, they found that with a minimum of 60 minutes a day there were increase in academic behavior, cognitive skills and attitudes.<ref>https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/health_and_academics/pdf/pa-pe_paper.pdf</ref>
The communities that support walking buses may see reduced congestion around school grounds. The walking bus is a non-polluting and sustainable transport alternative to cars and buses. In regards to the safety of the walking bus; the section about Safe Routes to School below goes into more detail about improvements being made to increase the safety for commuting pedestrians.<ref>http://escholarship.org/uc/item/5455454c#page-3</ref>
The built environment plays the biggest role in whether or not a community is walkable. The [[built environment]] consists of the human made surroundings that affect one’s life. There are numerous factors that make up the built environment including the availability and quality of sidewalks, crosswalks and parks, the amount of traffic and proximity to schools/parks/shops, etc. These factors determine the [[walkability]] of an area.
Walkability has been shown to be closely tied to childhood obesity. One study found that “the chances of a child being obese or overweight were 20-60 percent higher among children in neighborhoods where it was not safe to walk around or where there were no sidewalks.” <ref name="Khan2011">{{Citation | title = Combating Obesity through the Built Environment: Is There a Clear Path to Success | year = 2011 | author = Khan, Fazal | journal = The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics | volume=39 |issue=3 | pages= 387–393 |doi=10.1111/j.1748-720X.2011.00608.x }}</ref> In addition, children in neighborhoods with sidewalks and safe places to cross the street are more likely to be physically active than children living in neighborhoods without those safe infrastructure elements.<ref>{{Citation|title=Do attributes in the physical environment influence children’s physical activity? A Review of the literature|year=2006|last1=Davison|last2=Lawson|first1=Kirsten|first2=Catherine|journal=International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity 3}}</ref>
The walking bus depends on a walkable and safe built environment. [http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/ Safe Routes to School] is US government program that funds improvements in the built environment near schools.
==Support for the walking bus==
===Health Benefits===
Children who walk or bicycle to school have higher daily levels of physical activity and better cardiovascular fitness than do children who do not actively commute to school.<ref>{{Citation | title = Children’s Active Commuting to School: Current Knowledge and Future Directions | year = 2008 | journal = Preventing Chronic Disease | volume = 5.3 | issue = A100 | last1 = Davison | first1 = Kirsten K. | last2 = Werder | first2 = Jessica L. | last3 = Lawson | first3 = Catherine T. }}</ref> In a study of adolescents, 100% of the students who walked both to and from school met the recommended levels of 60 or more minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity on weekdays.<ref>{{Citation|title=The Broader Impact of Walking to School Among Adolescents: Seven Day Accelerometry Based Study|year=2005|last1=Alexander|last2=Inchley|last3=Currie|first1=Leslie M.|first2=Jo|first3=Candace|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=331|pages=1061–1062|doi=10.1136/bmj.38567.382731.ae|pmid=16107430|pmc=1283187}}</ref>
In a pilot, randomized controlled trial (RCT) in Houston, Texas, children that were assigned to a Walking School Bus group increased their weekly rate of active commuting by 38.0% over a five-week period, while children assigned to a no intervention group decreased their active commuting rate by a small margin.<ref>{{Citation | title = The walking school bus and children’s physical activity: A pilot cluster randomized control trial | journal = Pediatrics | pages = 537–544 | volume = 128 | issue = 3 | last1 = Mendoza | first1 = J.A. | last2 = Watson | first2 = K. | last3 = Baranowski | first3 = T. | last4 = Nicklas | first4 = T.A. | last5 = Uscanga | first5 = D.K. | last6 = Hanfling | first6 = M.J. }}</ref>
===Policies and regulations===
In 2005, the US Federal Transportation Reauthorization Bill—The Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act (SAFETEA-LU 109-59) was passed which provided nearly $1 billion funding to all states for Safe Routes to School (SRTS) programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://guide.saferoutesinfo.org/introduction/history_of_srts.cfm|title=SRTS Guide: History of Safe Routes to School|website=guide.saferoutesinfo.org|access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> The program's purpose is to: “enable and encourage children, including those with disabilities, to walk and bicycle to school; to make walking and bicycling to school safe and more appealing; and to facilitate the planning, development and implementation of projects that will improve safety, and reduce traffic, fuel consumption, and air pollution in the vicinity of schools.” It is a 100% federally funded program which is administered by state departments of transportation. Money goes towards infrastructure-related programs in addition to non-infrastructure activities such as education and enforcement-year time period, restricting data to school-travel hours.
This law is central to the success of programs like the Walking Bus because it identifies the many components involved. Active transport to school and examples such as the walking school bus require collaboration from many different sectors (transportation, law enforcement, school policies, and local government to name a few). In addition, the ability to create an environment conducive to walkability is dependent on the built environment as well as numerous policies from these various sectors. <ref>{{Citation | title = Policies related to active transport to and from school: A multisite case study | year = 2008 | journal = Health Education Research | pages = 963–975 | volume = 23 | issue = 6 | last1 = Eyler | first1 = A.A. | last2 = Brownson | first2 = R.C. | last3 = Doescher | first3 = M.P. | last4 = Evenson | first4 = K.R. | last5 = Fesperman | first5 = C.E. | last6 = Litt | first6 = J.S. | last7 = Pluto | first7 = D. | last8 = Steinman | first8 = L.E. | last9 = Terpstra | first9 = J.L. | last10 = Troped | first10 = P.J. | last11 = Schmid | first11 = T.L. | doi=10.1093/her/cym061}}</ref>
According to the Institute of Medicine Report, Measuring Progress in Obesity Prevention, the environment people live in can have a profound effect on the amount of physical activity which they engage in. According to James Sallis in his workshop presentation, informal or formal policies issued by the government or private sector, can affect physical activity in four ways. First, zoning, building codes, public transportation and recreational facility policies affect ability to engage in physical activity. Second, policies affecting physical activity in schools—physical education classes, recess, and walkability to and from school. Policies providing incentives such as parking and commuting in other ways, and insurance subsidies promote walkability and physical activity for adults. Finally funding policies have a strong influence on physical activity. The 2005 federal law supporting safe Routes to School is meant to facilitate physical activity and increase walkability.<ref name=Report2012>{{Citation | title = Measuring Progress in Obesity Prevention | url = http://www.iom.edu/Reports/2012/Measuring-Progress-in-Obesity-Prevention.aspx | year = 2012 | author = Report, Workshop | accessdate = 2012-07-18 }}</ref>
Two national programs that focus on physical activity environment policies are the Health and Human Services Healthy People 2020 and the National Physical Activity Plan, sponsored by numerous organizations including the YMCA, the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Association. The plan is a public-private partnership to create policies that promote physical activity for all individuals. Healthy People 2020 lists objectives to boost physical activity and also supports the recording of national data to track interventions. These are two examples of policies to promote physical activity. The Walking School Bus fits into their programs because it increases activity and translates a sedentary time of the day (transport in car or bus to school) to an active one.<ref>{{Citation | title = Healthy People 2020 | url = http://www.healthypeople.gov/2020/default.aspx | year = 2010 | accessdate = 2012-07-18 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = National Physical Activity Plan | url = http://www.physicalactivityplan.org/ | year = 2012 | accessdate = 2012-07-18 }}</ref>
== Safe Routes to School == Pedestrian injuries have found to be associated with the built environment elements, rather than with increased walking to school.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rothman|first=Linda|last2=Macarthur|first2=Colin|last3=To|first3=Teresa|last4=Buliung|first4=Ron|last5=Howard|first5=Andrew|date=2014-05-01|title=Motor Vehicle-Pedestrian Collisions and Walking to School: The Role of the Built Environment|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/133/5/776|journal=Pediatrics|language=en|volume=133|issue=5|pages=776–784|doi=10.1542/peds.2013-2317|issn=0031-4005|pmid=24709929}}</ref> [http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/ Safe Routes to School] (SRTS) provides federal funds for improvements of the [[built environment]] near schools with the goal of increasing walking and biking to school.
The effectiveness of SRTS has been demonstrated in multiple studies. One national study analyzed data across 18 states over 16 years. The study compared rates of pedestrian/bicyclist injury in school-aged children to adults, restricting data to school-travel hours. While adult injury rates were largely unchanged over the study period, implementation of SRTS was associated with around a 20% reduction in both in pedestrian/bicyclist injury and fatality risk in children.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DiMaggio|first=Charles|last2=Frangos|first2=Spiros|last3=Li|first3=Guohua|date=2016-06-01|title=National Safe Routes to School program and risk of school-age pedestrian and bicyclist injury|journal=Annals of Epidemiology|volume=26|issue=6|pages=412–417|doi=10.1016/j.annepidem.2016.04.002|issn=1873-2585|pmid=27230492}}</ref> In Texas, traffic crash data over 5 years showed that pedestrian and bicyclist injuries decreased about 40% after implementation of SRTS.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=DiMaggio|first=Charles|last2=Brady|first2=Joanne|last3=Li|first3=Guohua|date=2015-12-01|title=Association of the Safe Routes to School program with school-age pedestrian and bicyclist injury risk in Texas|journal=Injury Epidemiology|volume=2|issue=1|pages=15|doi=10.1186/s40621-015-0038-3|pmc=5005687|pmid=27747747}}</ref> In New York city, SRTS decreased pedestrian injury by one-third in school-age children.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Dimaggio|first=Charles|last2=Li|first2=Guohua|date=2013-02-01|title=Effectiveness of a safe routes to school program in preventing school-aged pedestrian injury|journal=Pediatrics|volume=131|issue=2|pages=290–296|doi=10.1542/peds.2012-2182|issn=1098-4275|pmc=3557410|pmid=23319533}}</ref>
The benefits of SRTS may extend beyond children. While the national study showed adult pedestrian injury risk unchanged, both the Texas and New York studies have demonstrated reduced pedestrian injury risk in adults with SRTS interventions.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
SRTS programs are also effective in increasing walking and bicycling. In California, the effect of SRTS implementation varied widely but rates of observed walking and biking to school increased by 20 to 200%.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=R.|first=Orenstein, Marla|last2=Nicolas|first2=Gutierrez,|last3=M.|first3=Rice, Thomas|last4=F.|first4=Cooper, Jill|last5=R.|first5=Ragland, David|date=2007-04-01|title=Safe Routes to School Safety and Mobility Analysis|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/5455454c#page-3|journal=Safe Transportation Research & Education Center}}</ref>
== Bicycle train == '''Bicycle train''' is the same concept but instead of walking the children and adult(s) move by bicycle.<ref>[http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/guide/encouragement/walking_school_bus_or_bicycle_train.cfm SRTS Guide: Walking School Buses and Bicycle Trains] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104163517/http://www.saferoutesinfo.org/guide/encouragement/walking_school_bus_or_bicycle_train.cfm |date=2011-01-04 }} - National Center for Safe Routes to School</ref>
==Problems== In Japan, some traffic accidents have occurred that resulted in the death of multiple schoolkids who were walking to school in a group.<ref>{{Cite news|title=無免許運転の少年、懲役5-8年判決 亀岡10人死傷|newspaper=Asahi Shimbun|date=2013-02-19|url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0219/OSK201302190066.html|accessdate=2013-02-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130219133350/http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0219/OSK201302190066.html|archivedate=2013-02-19}}</ref><ref>[http://www.47news.jp/CN/201112/CN2011121901001278.html クレーン車元運転手に懲役7年 6児童死亡で宇都宮地裁] 47NEWS 2011年12月19日</ref> In response to these accidents, schools have chosen to let their students walk to school via different paths, and cities have chosen to reduce speed limits, install road guards, and paint pedestrian zones to reduce the chance of accidents occurring again.<ref name="朝日5月23日">{{Cite news|title=通学路の安全 模索|newspaper=朝日新聞デジタル|date=2012-05-23|url=http://mytown.asahi.com/kyoto/news.php?k_id=27000001205230001|accessdate=2012-05-23}}{{dead link|date=November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=亀岡の事故現場、速度制限を30キロに|newspaper=朝日新聞|date=2012-05-29|url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK201205290019.html|accessdate=2012-05-31|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120602181727/http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK201205290019.html|archivedate=2012-06-02}}</ref>
